I’ve been thinking a lot lately about my role in life, what my proper function is in this world. It’s an age-old existential question: “Why am I here?” It’s all too easy to fall into a cynical pit of despair, esp. in this hyper-connected world. All you have to do is see the news & you can easily start adopting a combative nihilistic attitude- “Look at all this strife, both domestically & internationally– what’s the point?” And maybe things are, in fact, pointless– maybe we are screwed. However, if that’s the case, I know I feel better in this pointless existence if I’m at least TRYING to make things better- I also don’t like giving up, it feels weak. So I have to look at what I’m good at; what my history has qualified me to do- in a macro sense, I’m good at making music, writing, & photography- I’m an artist. Two books: “10 Arguments For Deleting Your Social Media Right Now” by Jaron Lanier & “Digital Minimalism” by Cal Newport. Both logically flesh out a glaringly obvious problem: we spend way too much time looking at little screens, & as a result we are suffering. Sean Parker, billionaire inventor of Napster & early Facebook investor spoke publicly at a 2017 Axios event about designing social media’s addictive properties: 'The inventors, creators—it's me, it's Mark [Zuckerberg], it's Kevin Systrom on Instagram, it's all of these people--understood this consciously. And we did it anyway.' I know that I spend way too much time looking at Instagram, YouTube, & the horror show 24/7 news cycle. So for 31 days I’m deleting Instagram/Youtube from my phone & moving my web browser to a folder off my home screen. For the news (which I compulsively check, constantly cross-referencing about 7 different outlets varying from far left to far right leaning in order to get a feel for the average “spin of the day”- WHY? I already know what they are going to say!), I’m only going to look at WWW.ALLSIDES.COM which presents 3 different stories on each major news item (one each from a left, right, & center weighted news network), with no ads. Instagram is my only social media, & as it has brought REAL-WORLD value to my life, not just “likes”, which are empty digital baubles designed to give cheap serotonin hits (real world value I’ve gotten: information & business connections in photography, writing, music, & acting/ the ability to promote other artists & charitable causes I support/ actual in-person lasting friendships/ & most importantly... a growing surfing posse 😂), I’m not ready to delete my account. But it’s obvious that I need to evaluate my relationship w/this technology, & change it for the better. Why am I posting this instead of just vanishing? Because I hope it will make YOU, the reader, dig deep & ask yourself an honest question: WHAT AM I ACTUALLY USING THIS TECHNOLOGY FOR? Does it make you feel NERVOUS to think about stepping away from it? If so, that might be worth examining. See you in 31 days with a report- live long & prosper. PUBLIC SERVICE ANNOUNCEMENT: I try & post this every summer, because it’s beach season & tons of people come from inland & every single year, WITHOUT FAIL, people drown because they do not understand the ocean & rip currents- just like a 22 year old dude from Iowa who died in Florida two days ago on his honeymoon- it was his first time swimming in the ocean. Inlanders, pay attention: THE OCEAN IS NOT A SWIMMING POOL OR A LAKE. It has its own rules, & you have to learn & respect them. A rip current is a sort of river flowing out into the ocean- if you are caught in one, it will carry you out to sea, & it will do so very quickly. If you are swimming or even standing in shallow water & notice that suddenly you are far away from the beach, & that you can’t seem to swim back, you are more than likely caught in a rip current. #1. DO NOT PANIC. A rip current isn’t going to carry you a mile out to sea, & it’s not gonna “suck you under”- there is no such thing as an “undertow” (yes, I know my band has a song called “The Undertow”.) Just chill & don’t try to fight it- if you panic & fight it, you will get tired quickly & drown. #2. DO NOT TRY TO SWIM DIRECTLY BACK TOWARDS SHORE- instead, SWIM PARALLEL TO SHORE- most of the time this will get you out of the rip current & you can make your way back. Rip currents are scary, even for experienced swimmers- I’ve been in the ocean since I was four years old, & a few years ago I got caught in a weird rip/sink hole thing at Manhattan Beach in Cali. I was starting to get freaked out until I just swam a mere ten yards to my right & popped out of it, no problem. One minute I was in knee deep water, & within seconds I was wondering why I was in up to my neck & couldn’t get back in- it was scary. DON’T PANIC & YOU WON’T DROWN. Also, if you are not a strong enough swimmer to swim the length of a football field no problem, you probably shouldn’t be cruising out into the ocean very far at all. Those are just facts. Ok, PSA done. Enjoy the beach, pick up your trash (& other peoples), & don’t forget sunscreen- there is nothing more tragic than ruining your vacation by looking like a boiled lobster & feeling like you’re ON FIRE.

“Shagri-La” 10.17.2019 The Pacific Ocean. (PLEASE SEE PREVIOUS POST) Today ends my 31 day social media hiatus (Instagram is my only form of social media.) What did I find? I’m a news/politics junkie, & still found myself checking multiple sites several times a day, even though I KNOW BETTER & am aware of sensationalism & bias in the news media, both left & right (heck, I even wrote a song about it, “Engage the Fear Machine”) Still I got suckered into the endless horror show, & made these douchebags more advertiser dollars with every click (because that is what it’s all about people- ADVERTISING DOLLARS.) As an alcoholic who has been sober several years now, I’m keenly aware of when I’m displaying addictive behavior- it doesn’t feel good. These “smart phones” (originally solely designed just so you wouldn’t have to carry an iPod & a phone at the same time) are distraction machines. So I’m installing an app that restricts the web browser on my phone in order to curtail this ridiculous news habit of mine. Sad, but true. I took this photo on a cruise ship my band played on- as we were at sea, there was no cell service or internet. I heard people complaining as if this was some sort of savage punishment- for me, it was paradise, hence the title of this photo (if you don’t know what Shangri-La is, read “Lost Horizon”- in fact, just read a book in general. “Shine on, Bright Star” Hollywood, CA. 1.5.2019 It is with a heavy heart that I must bid this young man, @thecameronboyce, a peaceful journey on his trip to the great beyond. I met Cameron working in Hollywood- we did some acting together for an upcoming production. Cameron was a Disney child actor, now growing into a young man- he was just 20 years old when he died last night of natural causes due to an ongoing medical condition. Despite being famous as a child star, he was as about as down to earth as a person could get, which greatly impressed me- there was absolutely zero sense of entitlement about him. We had a lot of laughs on set, not to mention good talks on the nature & perils of fame. Cameron was incredibly talented- he could dance, sing, & was a brilliant actor with a great sense of humor & a genuine curiosity about the world- just truly a joy to watch perform. I would watch him on set doing his thing & think “Man- he’s SO GOOD.” Incidentally, his paternal grandmother, Jo Ann (Allen) Boyce, is a Civil Rights icon, one of the first 12 African-Americans to attend an integrated high school in the south, in 1956- I believe that this sort of upbringing lead to his strength of character, & philanthropic nature. Although he & I came from very different worlds- the Disney scene & the heavy metal music world are pretty much polar opposites- we got along well & I was really looking forward to seeing & working with him again. I extend my most sincere condolences to Cameron’s family & friends. The world needs more socially aware & kind hearted young men, & we certainly lost a good one last night. I took this photo on set- you can see the kindness in his eyes. DEAD WEIGHT. Earlier this year I had skydive accident that I didn’t see coming while working a commercial. As you can see from this picture I pretty much look dead. My canopy deployed instantaneously. So instead of going from 130 Ish mph to maybe 20 mph gradually over 6-10 seconds it happened in about a half second. Which was like getting hit by a truck. the impact of the jerk was so harsh I actually thought someone else ran into me in the air. The initial jerk blacked me out from the G- forces, bruised my chin on my chest from it hitting it and vice Versa, caused 2 full leg strap bruises, bent and tweaked my back as it stopped me and kinked my neck and cracked my neck like I’ve never had happen before. As you can see the filmer @travisfienhage caught the whole opening right in front of him, which isn’t normal. I got lucky, my buddy @brandonlillard broke his back on something similar and I was told necks get broken like this every once in awhile. Luckily I fully came too about 30-60 seconds after this. Took a few seconds to evaluate myself shake off the daze as much as I could check my gear and fly to my landing area where I came in on my butt and just sat there for a bit cause I was still very much in pain and disoriented. Thankful I have guys like @travisfienhage in my corner constantly testing me and reminding me to stay up to date, aware and just all around in general never to get complacent in what we do. We studied the footage to see if I had done something that caused it - Still not sure why it happened, could of been the packers error not tucking my slider correct, could of been just dumb luck, doesn’t much matter to me - but I learned a huge lesson that day - things happen you have no control over. All you can do is be mentally prepared for it all. #betheadventure #skydive #outdoors #slam #canopy @gopro #gopro #gpathlete

For the small peasants, who have kept us alive for thousands of years.
For all those who through the centuries have protected springs and forests to leave our children a planet as fertile as they found it.
Let us pray.
For all those peasants without a name who have preserved seeds and guarded their know-how and given it – not sold it – to the future generations. For all those peasants who have protected and delivered us the greatest wealth there is: biodiversity.
Let us pray.
For the unknown person who planted the hedges to live together with animals and insects, who planted trees to give shade and relief to flocks and shepherds.
For all those who didn’t poison what feeds us.
Let us pray.
For all those peasants who suffered misery and poverty but offered the world beauties and marvels and landscapes.
For this moving testimony whereby human beings can live in harmony with nature, not geared toward profit and without destroying all ressources.
For all those peasants who have been exploited and humiliated by the landlords of all the times.
Let us pray.

I work frequently around walls. The walls that separate, (Face2Face and Kikito); the walls that are destroyed at a loss for the memory of a place (Wrinkles of the City, Destruction serie in Les Bosquets); the walls that we try to build again, in concrete or in our minds. The Brandenburg Gate was part of a wall that represented the division of Europe following the failure of a mass murder ideology. It separated women and men who lived in two opposite systems of thought. The opening of this Gate has kindled a wind of freedom that has engulfed millions of Europeans

Pace is pleased to present 'The Chronicles of San Francisco - Sketches,' an exhibition of new work by French artist and photographer JR (@jr), on view at Pace’s gallery in Palo Alto from February 6 – March 24, 2019. Encompassing portraits, works on paper, video installations, lightboxes, and etched glass works, the exhibition is derived from and inspired by JR's upcoming monumental mural project 'The Chronicles of San Francisco,' opening at SFMOMA (@SFMOMA) in Spring 2019.
-
Known for his large-scale urban works that address socio-economic and political issues, JR created the new series in honor of the city and people of #SanFrancisco. The city’s long muralist tradition and its stark contrasts—featuring both immense innovation and wealth as well as one of the country’s highest rates of child homelessness—has made it a vibrant and complex site for the artist to explore and capture. Over the course of the project, nearly 1,200 people were filmed, photographed and interviewed; each person choosing the way they were to be represented in the mural.
-
“In a painting, it’s usually the perspective that focuses the attention of the viewer. With this new mural technique, we break the perspective: Every person is presented at the same size, captured with the same light. No one is more important than another. It is not a group photo, but rather a group of photos...The mural aims to be a picture of society, not depicting good and bad, but rather showing that both sides are present in everyone.”—#JR

The first time I photographed Alex Honnold was over a decade ago when our respective cars were our castles, means of transport, and kitchens. I remember the drive from Canada to Yosemite as a jittery sprint fueled by caffeine and gas station cashews. The pictures I took of Alex back then left me wanting, as if there were a depth to his character that was expressed through his action but escaped my ability as a photographer. He struck me as an athlete more sculpted by his medium than any other I’d met. I wondered if his physical form was a necessary response to repeated stimuli or if he represented something entirely unique. Photographing him all these years later was an opportunity to celebrate him as form born of the stone he surrounds himself with, seeing him as wholly human but somehow simultaneously transcendent of that definition. It's easy to convince ourselves that environments have moods...and certainly there are belief systems that would hold to that. I tend to think that we bring our emotions to the mountains...and the mountains themselves are the planet's greatest mirror.

On the day I took this image in 2016, we climbed through snow and cloud. The heat caused by the convection cycle triggered repeated small avalanches that would rumble over seracs obscured by a thick fog on either side. This day, and the mood that I was bringing to it was reminiscent of a not so good day I had in the mountains several years ago when one of the distant rumbles became not so distant and engulfed my partners and I. My neuro-chemistry has never recovered.

That day I was looking in the mirror at a fear that I've never overcome. That day, because I was angry, the mountains were angry. As I climbed the slope beneath the seracs (which are almost as safe as they come), I felt my heart rate increase and my breathing become labored. I was scared, and that made me mad.

But the truth is the mountains are indiscriminate. They don't care. They shine when it is sunny and they fall when it is snowy. It's what we bring to them that defines our experience...and maybe even more important, its how we are changed by them and what we bring home and share that matters most.

I am excited, scared, humbled to experience how the mountains will change me on this new journey through a familiar - yet different - landscape.

Throughout the journey to summit Southeast Asia’s highest peak, Hkakabo Razi, the team and I passed by many religious sites such as Mingun Pahtodawgi near Mandalay, pictured here.

This site has a fascinating history. These remains are the intentionally unfinished stupa project of King Bbodawpaya. The building of the temple took a tremendous toll on the state and resources and, as a result, a false prophecy was created to slowly stop the project. The prophecy has many iterations since creation, but it generally stated that when the project was complete the king would die. At abandonment, Mingun Pahtodawgi stood only 1/3 of it’s intended 150 meter height.

King Bodawpaya also had a 90 ton bell cast to accompany the pagoda, and it still, to this day, holds the record of the 2nd largest ringing bell in the world.

As many of you who have followed me already know, I have -and will continue to- navigate my challenges with mental health. I have a complicated relationship with social media, and regardless of the bad that comes with this platform, I have experienced the positive that comes with loudly and consistently vocalizing around the topic of Mental Health Awareness. It’s obvious that images of mountains and climbing get the most likes, BUT anytime I post about a personal struggle with mental health, I receive the most comments, private messages and emails. Veterans, stay-at-home parents, athletes, students, women, men..you name the type of person, I can guarantee they have reached out.
.
I encourage voicing the struggles you may experience if you struggle with Mental Health. You are not in this alone, and it’s not just about “being more happy.” Being vulnerable and vocalizing my challenges was the beginning of finding my individual way through PTSD + Anxiety. It helped me find the right people in my life -the ones that listen, care, empathize and understand. I also encourage anyone and everyone that struggles to find the right professional resources for them. The digital world provides opportunity to find and connect with professionals like never before. .
I also encourage those that might not understand what mental health is to google it, read about it, understand it. For a moment, imagine yourself in the skin of another that battles with mental health. Learn to empathize because I guarantee that if you aren’t experiencing it, you are surrounded by people that are. .
On this world Mental Health Day, I encourage you to share below your stories, resources and questions. We are already a community here, let’s use it to our advantage.

In 2014, I had the honor to travel on the behalf of #natgeo to Franz Josef Land (FJL), an #arctic Russian archipelago inhabited only by military personnel. Similarly to last post, I witnessed first-hand the changing, melting landscape of pristine land. Since this #expedition, scientific studies have concluded that “ice mass loss from 2011-2015 has doubled compared to any previous time spans”. Glacier retreat has been widespread and has led to the creation of at least one new island. Ice wastage, which means the removal of snow or ice from a glacier, was historically relatively small, but accelerating ice loss is the new normal for FJL.

We don’t need to travel to the arctic to experience our changing environment. There are shifts occurring here in my home of the United States, which some of you have spoken about in yesterday’s post’s comment section. To me, this isn’t a political debate, so let’s continue the conversation about our experiences and how to personally shift to make better choices - better choices for ourselves and our present *and future* global community.

the captions for these will be my musings on the benefits of sidework for creatives.

last week i introduced you to the volunteer bookstore. this week i’m introducing you to my new job as a forklift operator. kidding. i’m introducing you to thursdays with ed.

ed is a film historian and author of a bunch of amazing books. he likes a lot of the same movies as me and is pretty mischevious. he’s in his mid 60s and has parkinson’s. he gets around okay but struggles with certain motor functions from time to time and going outside can be daunting. parkinson’s is a nasty disease. he never knows when his legs might lock up, leaving him frozen in a busy manhattan intersection.

my job is basically to help him get to a couple appointments and make sure he doesn’t fall over. i also consider it part of my job to make sure ed has a nice day on thursdays. i do what i can.

that first day, i didn’t know what to expect. i’d never looked after someone with parkinson’s. (i can barely look after myself!) within 5 minutes right after we shook hands he fell over. it wasn’t a hard fall: he landed on his bed. his husband showed me the easy way to get him back on his feet (good to know!) but i thought oh great, i’m gonna be picking this guy up a lot!

now, after a few months, we’ve had a lot of wonderful thursdays. we’ve gone to the movies (the dead don’t die!), talked about religion in the park, discussed love and regrets and had many belly laughs. and since that first day, ed hasn’t fallen once!

the other day, ed noted how few “episodes” he’d had lately. “i hope you’re not about to fire me” i said. he replied “i’d make up symptoms to keep you around.” it’s nice to feel wanted. and thursdays with ed have put me in a different head space than anything i’ve experienced. i’m reflective and protective and i love it.

last week, i told ed about my project about the benefits of side work and i asked him if it was okay if i started writing about our thursdays. “i could call you fred?” he said “you better call me ed. and after all the embarrasing things i’ve written about other people, you better embarrass me.”

“I was shooting in Mumbai city for a book project in 1996. I had heard of local trains arriving into the city with a human deluge that was unmeasurable, a flood of people who would then be dispersed to their places of work. Sure enough, I reached Churchgate railway station–the busiest place in the heart of the city–at 8 a.m. I stood there in awe and amazement, with an unimaginable and overpowering feeling of the deluge. It took less than a minute for thousands of commuters to disappear. The platform was empty again until 3 or 4 minutes later, when more trains arrived to bring in another deluge. .
